Stem: Graph of bicycle speed over time. Drop-down Part A: Energy is greatest at time ___. Part B: because speed was ___.
Image/Diagram Description: Graph showing bicycle speed at different time points (X and others)
Choices: Part A: Time W / Time X / Time Y / Time Z; Part B: the slowest / the fastest / zero / constant
Scenario Justification: Real-world scenario using a graph of bicycle speed over time. Students must interpret data to determine when kinetic energy is greatest. The two-part structure requires connecting speed data to energy concepts. Anchored in an observable phenomenon.
SEP Justification: Students analyze and interpret graphical data to draw a conclusion about energy. The two-part structure engages Constructing Explanations by requiring students to identify the data point AND justify with reasoning about the speed-energy relationship.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that kinetic energy is related to speed — greater speed means greater energy. Students must apply this concept to a graphical representation rather than simply recalling the definition.
CCC Justification: Engages Energy and Matter — students reason about how speed (observable) relates to kinetic energy (concept). Also engages Cause and Effect — speed being fastest causes energy to be greatest.
Key Recommendation: Good two-part data interpretation question. Elevate by adding a Part C asking students to predict what happens to energy when the bicycle stops and explain why using Cause and Effect reasoning.

Stem: Which of the following are examples of energy transfer due to collisions on a baseball field?
Choices: A) Ball hitting a bat, B) Ball hitting the ground, C) Ball hitting a glove, D) All of the above
Scenario Justification: Baseball field context provides a real-world setting but the question asks students to identify collision examples rather than reason about them. The correct answer (all of the above) reduces cognitive demand since each option is obviously a collision.
SEP Justification: Students identify examples of collisions. Limited practice engagement — classification/recognition rather than analysis or explanation. No deeper scientific reasoning required.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding that collisions involve energy transfer. All three examples are obvious collisions making the question recall-level. No reasoning about HOW energy transfers in each case.
CCC Justification: No CCC explicitly engaged. Students are not reasoning about patterns, cause and effect, or energy flow — just identifying instances.
Key Recommendation: 'All of the above' format removes reasoning demand. Redesign to ask students to compare energy transfers across the three collisions — which transfers the most energy and why? This would engage Cause and Effect and deepen DCI application.

Stem: Two billiard balls collide and produce a sound. Why does this happen?
Choices: A) Kinetic energy is transferred from one ball to the other causing vibration that produces sound, B) Sound energy was already stored inside the balls, C) The table surface creates the sound, D) The balls absorb all energy so no sound should occur
Scenario Justification: Real phenomenon — billiard ball collision producing sound. Students must explain the mechanism of energy transfer from kinetic to sound through vibration. Genuine causal reasoning required.
SEP Justification: Students construct an explanation for an observed phenomenon. Engages Constructing Explanations by requiring a causal mechanism (kinetic energy → vibration → sound) rather than just naming the process.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that collisions transfer kinetic energy and that vibrations from the collision produce sound energy. Goes beyond recall to explaining the mechanism of energy conversion.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect — collision (cause) transfers kinetic energy creating vibration that produces sound (effect). Multi-step causal chain reasoning required.
Key Recommendation: Good causal reasoning question about energy transfer in collisions. Elevate by asking a follow-up: What would change about the sound if the balls collided with greater speed? This deepens the Cause and Effect reasoning.

Stem: A rubber band is stretched and used to launch a marble across a table. What causes the marble to move?
Choices: A) The energy stored in the stretched rubber band, B) The weight of the marble, C) The friction of the table, D) The air pushing the marble
Scenario Justification: Real observable scenario — rubber band launching a marble. Students must identify the energy source that causes motion. Concrete and testable phenomenon.
SEP Justification: Students identify the cause of motion. Engages Constructing Explanations at a basic level by linking stored energy to motion. However the question is essentially selecting the correct energy source rather than constructing a full explanation.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that elastic potential energy stored in the stretched rubber band converts to kinetic energy of the marble. Applied understanding of energy conversion.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect — stretched rubber band (cause) releases stored energy causing marble to move (effect). Basic causal reasoning but not deeply developed.
Key Recommendation: Good scenario but the question is essentially identifying the energy source. Strengthen by asking students to explain what would happen if the rubber band were stretched MORE or LESS and why, engaging Energy and Matter reasoning about proportional relationships.

Stem: A diagram shows layers of rock with fossils. Which statement describes the ages of the fossils?
Image/Diagram Description: Diagram showing fossil layers with Layer 1 at top and deeper layers below
Choices: A) Fossils in Layer 1 are the oldest, B) Fossils in Layer 1 are the youngest because it is the top layer, C) All fossils are the same age, D) Layer 1 fossils are the oldest because they formed first
Scenario Justification: Diagram-based fossil layer question. Students must apply superposition to determine relative fossil ages. The diagram provides visual evidence that requires interpretation.
SEP Justification: Students apply the principle of superposition to determine relative ages. Engages Analyzing and Interpreting Data from a diagram but the reasoning is a direct application of a known rule.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding the principle of superposition — top layers are youngest, bottom layers are oldest. Applied in context with a specific diagram rather than abstract recall.
CCC Justification: Implicitly engages Patterns (layer ordering as a pattern of age) and Stability and Change (layers represent change over time) but neither is explicitly required as a reasoning tool.
Key Recommendation: Standard superposition question. Strengthen by providing fossils of organisms across multiple layers and asking students to reconstruct the environmental history using Patterns reasoning.

Stem: A paleontologist made sketches of fossils found in different rock layers. Which statement is true?
Image/Diagram Description: Diagram showing plant fossils and animal fossils in different rock layers with plant fossils in lower/older layers
Choices: A) The plant fossils are the oldest because they are in the deepest layer, B) The animal fossils are oldest because animals existed first, C) All fossils formed at the same time, D) The plant fossils are youngest because plants grow last
Scenario Justification: Real scientific context with a paleontologist's observations. Students must interpret rock layer position to determine relative fossil age. The paleontologist framing adds authenticity.
SEP Justification: Students analyze evidence from rock layers to draw a conclusion about relative ages. Engages Analyzing and Interpreting Data from a scientific representation. The paleontologist context engages authentic scientific practice.
DCI Justification: Requires applying superposition to determine that deeper layers contain older fossils. Applied understanding of relative dating through rock layer evidence.
CCC Justification: Implicitly engages Patterns (layer position correlates with age) but students do not explicitly use the CCC as a reasoning tool.
Key Recommendation: Good scientific context but similar to Q5. Strengthen by asking a Part B: What does the sequence of fossils (plants in deep layers, animals above) suggest about the history of life in this area?

Stem: Select TWO sentences that describe erosion.
Choices: A) A river deposits sediment at its mouth, B) Acid rain dissolves the surface of a limestone statue, C) Rainwater moves soil from the top of a hill to the bottom, D) Tree roots grow into cracks and break rock apart, E) Wind blows sand from one area to a different area
Scenario Justification: No real-world scenario. Students must distinguish erosion from deposition and weathering. Requires classification of processes rather than application or reasoning within a phenomenon.
SEP Justification: Students classify processes as erosion vs. other Earth surface processes. Engages Analyzing and Interpreting Data at a basic classification level — identifying which descriptions match erosion.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding the specific definition of erosion (movement of weathered material by natural agents) and distinguishing it from deposition (A), chemical weathering (B), and mechanical weathering (D). Applied classification.
CCC Justification: Implicitly engages Cause and Effect (agents like water and wind cause material movement) but the reasoning is at a classification level rather than causal analysis.
Key Recommendation: Classification question rather than phenomenon-based. Redesign to present a real landscape scenario and ask students to identify and explain which processes are erosion and which are weathering or deposition.

Stem: After a rainstorm two hills are observed. Hill A has more loose soil at the bottom. Why does Hill A have more erosion?
Image/Diagram Description: None or simple diagram of two hills
Choices: A) Hill A has fewer plants to hold soil in place, B) Hill A is made of harder rock, C) Hill A receives less rain, D) Hill A is shorter than Hill B
Scenario Justification: Comparative observation scenario with two hills after a rainstorm. Students must reason about what factor causes one hill to erode more than the other. Genuine causal reasoning required.
SEP Justification: Students construct an explanation for a comparative observation. Engages Constructing Explanations by identifying the factor (fewer plants) that causes different erosion outcomes between two hills.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that plant roots stabilize soil and reduce erosion. Applied understanding of how living things affect Earth surface processes.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect — fewer plants (cause) leads to more erosion (effect). Students must reason about what variable explains the difference between the two hills.
Key Recommendation: Good comparative reasoning question. Elevate by providing data on plant coverage percentages and erosion amounts for multiple hills and asking students to identify the pattern and explain the relationship.

Stem: Which of the following describe how physical weathering can impact landforms? Select ALL that apply.
Choices: A) Volcanic eruptions create new mountains, B) Water flowing through rock forms canyons over time, C) Earthquakes create new fault lines, D) Temperature changes cause rocks to expand and contract leading to weathering
Scenario Justification: No specific scenario. Students must identify examples of physical weathering from a list that includes non-weathering processes. Classification task with some reasoning about what qualifies as physical weathering.
SEP Justification: Students classify processes as physical weathering vs. other geological processes. Engages Analyzing and Interpreting Data at a classification level — distinguishing weathering from volcanism and tectonics.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding what constitutes physical weathering (mechanical breakdown of rock by water, temperature changes) and distinguishing it from constructive processes. Applied classification with reasoning.
CCC Justification: Implicitly engages Cause and Effect (water and temperature cause weathering) and Stability and Change (landforms change through weathering) but not deeply developed.
Key Recommendation: Classification question about weathering processes. Redesign to provide a specific landform with evidence of weathering and ask students to explain which physical weathering processes acted on it and how.

Stem: Water freezes inside cracks in a rock. What happens to the rock over time?
Choices: A) The rock becomes smoother, B) The rock gets larger, C) The rock changes color, D) The rock breaks into smaller pieces
Scenario Justification: Simple cause-and-effect scenario about frost wedging. Students must know that water expands when it freezes and this breaks rock apart. Minimal reasoning beyond recall of the process.
SEP Justification: Students select the correct outcome of freeze-thaw weathering. Engages Constructing Explanations at a basic level but the correct answer is essentially recall of a known process.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of frost wedging — water expands when freezing and breaks rock. Recall-level with minimal application.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect — water freezing (cause) breaks rock apart (effect). Basic causal reasoning but at a recall level.
Key Recommendation: Essentially recall of frost wedging. Redesign to provide data about freeze-thaw cycles in different climates and ask students to predict which locations would show more weathering and explain why.

Stem: The Sun and a bonfire both produce the same two types of energy. Which TWO types of energy do they both produce?
Choices: A) Thermal/heat energy, B) Sound energy, C) Electrical energy, D) Light energy
Scenario Justification: Simple comparison of two heat/light sources. Students must identify shared energy types. No deeper reasoning about energy production mechanisms or differences.
SEP Justification: No science practice beyond recall and classification. Students identify energy types produced by two sources. No analysis or explanation required.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding that both the Sun and bonfires produce heat and light energy. Recall-level classification of energy types from common sources.
CCC Justification: No CCC explicitly engaged. Students are not reasoning about patterns, systems, or causation.
Key Recommendation: Pure recall of energy types. Redesign to provide data about the proportions of heat vs. light energy from different sources and ask students to compare and explain the patterns.

Stem: How is electric current energy different from sound wave energy?
Choices: A) Electric current moves in waves and sound does not, B) Sound energy can be stored but electric current cannot, C) Electric current is always visible but sound is not, D) Electric currents can be turned on and off
Scenario Justification: Comparative question about two forms of energy. Students must distinguish properties of electrical current from sound wave energy. Some reasoning about energy properties required.
SEP Justification: Students compare and contrast energy forms. Engages Analyzing and Interpreting Data at a basic comparison level. Limited practice depth — selecting the correct distinguishing characteristic.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of properties of electrical current vs. sound energy. The correct answer (can be turned on/off) is a practical property rather than a deep physical distinction. Somewhat superficial DCI application.
CCC Justification: Implicitly engages Patterns (comparing properties across energy types) but at a very basic level. No explicit CCC reasoning required.
Key Recommendation: The distinguishing characteristic (on/off) is superficial and not physically rigorous — sound can also be started and stopped. Redesign to compare HOW energy travels (waves vs. current through conductors) and ask students to explain the differences using Energy and Matter reasoning.

Stem: Which diagram shows how a person sees an object?
Image/Diagram Description: Diagrams showing different light paths between a light source and an eye and an object
Choices: A) Light going from eye to object, B) Light going from object to eye without a source, C) Light from source reflecting off object into eye, D) Light from eye reflecting off object to source
Scenario Justification: Image-based question about the mechanism of vision. Students must select the correct model showing light traveling from a source, reflecting off an object, and entering the eye. Requires understanding of a multi-step process.
SEP Justification: Students evaluate competing models of how vision works. Engages Developing and Using Models by selecting the diagram that correctly represents light behavior for vision. Students must understand and evaluate visual models.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that we see objects because light from a source reflects off the object and enters our eyes. Goes beyond simple recall to selecting a correct model from alternatives including common misconceptions.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect — light from source (cause) reflects off object and enters eye (effect = vision). Also engages Systems and System Models — the vision system requires all three components (source, object, eye) in correct relationship.
Key Recommendation: Good model-evaluation question that addresses the common misconception of light emanating from eyes. Strengthen by asking a Part B: What would happen if the light source were removed? This deepens Cause and Effect reasoning.

Stem: A student can see a wall behind them by looking in a mirror. Why can the student see the wall in the mirror?
Choices: A) Light reflects off the mirror allowing the student to see the wall behind them, B) The mirror creates an image of the wall on its own, C) Sound waves from the wall bounce off the mirror, D) The mirror bends light from the student's eyes to the wall
Scenario Justification: Real-world scenario about seeing objects via mirror reflection. Students must explain the mechanism of mirror reflection for indirect vision. Practical and relatable phenomenon.
SEP Justification: Students select the correct explanation for mirror reflection. Engages Constructing Explanations at a basic level but the correct answer is a direct statement of the principle rather than a constructed explanation.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that mirrors reflect light and that this reflection allows us to see objects not in our direct line of sight. Applied understanding of light reflection.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect — light reflects off mirror (cause) allowing student to see wall (effect). Basic causal reasoning.
Key Recommendation: Good everyday scenario but the question is essentially selecting the correct principle statement. Strengthen by asking students to draw or describe the path of light from the wall to the mirror to the eye.

Stem: Why does a tree need internal structures to move water from its roots to its leaves?
Choices: A) To keep the roots wet, B) To help the tree produce seeds, C) To make sugars so the tree can grow, D) To help the tree change color in fall
Scenario Justification: Asks students to explain WHY trees need water transport structures by connecting to the function of water in photosynthesis and growth. Genuine reasoning about structure-function relationships.
SEP Justification: Students construct an explanation linking water transport structures to their purpose in sugar production and growth. Engages Constructing Explanations by connecting internal structures to their role in the organism's survival.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that water is needed for photosynthesis (making sugars) which enables growth. Goes beyond naming structures to explaining their functional importance in the organism's life processes.
CCC Justification: Engages Structure and Function — internal structures (xylem) serve the function of water transport needed for sugar production. Also engages Systems and System Models — water transport is part of the plant's interconnected life systems.
Key Recommendation: Good question connecting structure to function to survival. Elevate by providing data about water uptake rates in different conditions and asking students to explain what would happen to sugar production if water transport were impaired.

Stem: A bird spends most of its time swimming in ponds and lakes to find food. Which type of feet would this bird most likely have?
Image/Diagram Description: Images showing different bird foot types including webbed feet and others
Choices: A) Webbed feet, B) Talons/clawed feet, C) Long thin toes, D) Small perching feet
Scenario Justification: Image-based structure-function matching. Students must connect the habitat/behavior (swimming) to the appropriate foot structure. Some reasoning about adaptation but the connection is straightforward.
SEP Justification: Students match a structure to its function/habitat. Engages Constructing Explanations at a basic level — connecting webbed feet to swimming. Limited practice depth.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that webbed feet are an adaptation for swimming. Applied understanding of structure-function relationships in animal adaptations.
CCC Justification: Engages Structure and Function — webbed feet (structure) serve the function of swimming. Basic application of the CCC without deeper reasoning.
Key Recommendation: Simple structure-function matching. Redesign to present multiple bird feet images with habitat data and ask students to match each foot type to its habitat AND explain the structural features that make each foot suited to its environment.

Stem: Some snakes have special heat-sensing structures near their mouths. How do these structures support the snake's overall system for finding food?
Choices: A) They help the snake smell food from far away, B) They help the snake see in the dark using visible light, C) They send signals to the brain when a warm-blooded animal is nearby, D) They help the snake hear the movement of prey
Scenario Justification: Real biological phenomenon — snake heat-sensing pit organs. Students must reason about how a specific sensory structure supports the broader system of finding food. Genuine structure-function-system reasoning.
SEP Justification: Students construct an explanation for how a specific sensory structure supports the whole organism system. Engages Constructing Explanations with a systems-level perspective on how information flows from sensor to brain to behavior.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that heat-sensing structures detect infrared radiation from warm-blooded prey and transmit signals to the brain for processing. Applied understanding of sensory structures and information processing.
CCC Justification: Engages Systems and System Models — the heat-sensing structure is part of the nervous system that processes sensory information. Also engages Structure and Function — the specific structure serves the function of detecting thermal energy.
Key Recommendation: Good systems-level question about sensory structures. Elevate by asking a Part B: What advantage does heat sensing give snakes that hunt at night compared to snakes that rely only on vision?

Stem: Elephants have special sensory cells in their feet that can detect vibrations in the ground. How does this adaptation help elephants survive?
Choices: A) It signals the elephant if a predator is approaching from far away, B) It helps the elephant run faster, C) It allows the elephant to dig for water, D) It helps the elephant balance on rocky terrain
Scenario Justification: Real and fascinating biological phenomenon — elephant seismic communication through foot vibrations. Students must connect this sensory adaptation to survival advantage. Engaging and authentic context.
SEP Justification: Students construct an explanation linking a sensory adaptation to a survival benefit. Engages Constructing Explanations by reasoning about how detecting ground vibrations contributes to predator avoidance.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that sensory cells can detect vibrations and that this information helps the organism detect threats at a distance. Applied understanding of sensory adaptation and survival.
CCC Justification: Engages Structure and Function — sensory cells (structure) serve the function of detecting ground vibrations. Also engages Cause and Effect — vibrations from approaching predator (cause) trigger sensory cells enabling escape response (effect).
Key Recommendation: Good question about a fascinating adaptation. Elevate by presenting data about vibration detection ranges and predator approach speeds, asking students to explain how the adaptation provides a survival advantage.

Stem: Dogs have about 300 million smell receptors while rabbits have about 100 million. Why can dogs process more information about smells than rabbits?
Choices: A) Dogs have bigger noses, B) Dogs breathe faster than rabbits, C) Dogs have better eyesight that helps them smell, D) Dogs have about 10 times more smell receptors to detect odors
Scenario Justification: Comparative scenario with specific quantitative data about smell receptors in two animals. Students must connect receptor count to information processing capacity. Real biological data.
SEP Justification: Students select an explanation based on quantitative data. Engages Analyzing and Interpreting Data at a basic level — the answer is directly stated in the stem (300M vs 100M). Limited reasoning required beyond restating the given data.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that more sensory receptors means greater capacity to detect and process sensory information. Applied understanding of structure-function in sensory systems.
CCC Justification: Engages Structure and Function — more receptors (structure) means more information processing (function). Basic CCC application.
Key Recommendation: The answer is essentially restating information given in the stem (300M vs 100M = about 10x more). Redesign to provide receptor data for multiple animals and ask students to predict which can detect the faintest smells and explain the pattern.

Stem: A diagram shows an electric motor converting electrical energy to motion. Which device uses a similar energy conversion (electrical energy to motion)?
Image/Diagram Description: Diagram of an electric motor showing electrical energy input and motion output
Choices: A) A flashlight, B) A remote-controlled car, C) A solar panel, D) A campfire
Scenario Justification: Uses a diagram of energy conversion as a model and asks students to apply the same conversion pattern to another device. Students must identify which device converts electrical energy to motion energy.
SEP Justification: Students identify a device with the same energy conversion pattern. Engages Analyzing and Interpreting Data at a basic matching/transfer level. Limited practice depth — matching energy conversion patterns.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that electric motors convert electrical energy to motion energy and identifying this same conversion in a remote-controlled car. Applied understanding of energy conversion.
CCC Justification: Engages Patterns — students must recognize the same energy conversion pattern in a different device. Basic application of pattern recognition.
Key Recommendation: Good concept transfer question. Elevate by providing energy flow diagrams for each device and asking students to compare and explain which devices share conversion patterns and which differ.

Stem: Zoe wants to build an invention that converts electrical energy into both motion AND sound. Which component should she use?
Choices: A) A radio, B) A motor, C) A speaker, D) A light bulb
Scenario Justification: Engineering design context where a student must select a component based on energy conversion requirements. Students must reason about which device produces both motion and sound from electrical energy.
SEP Justification: Students evaluate options against design criteria. Engages Designing Solutions by selecting a component that meets specific energy conversion requirements (motion AND sound). Reasoning about dual outputs required.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding energy conversions of multiple devices and identifying which one produces both mechanical motion and sound (motors vibrate and create sound while producing motion). Applied understanding of energy conversion.
CCC Justification: Engages Energy and Matter — students reason about energy input (electrical) and multiple energy outputs (motion and sound). Basic CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: Good engineering design context. Strengthen by asking students to design a complete device that converts electrical energy through multiple stages and explain each conversion step.

Stem: Three diagrams show sound waves produced by three monkeys. A student claims Monkey 1 is the loudest. Is this claim accurate?
Image/Diagram Description: Diagrams showing sound waves with different amplitudes for three monkeys
Choices: A) Yes because Monkey 1 has the highest frequency, B) Yes because Monkey 1 has the longest wavelength, C) No because Monkey 1 has the lowest frequency, D) The answer depends on which wave has the greatest amplitude
Scenario Justification: Image-based wave comparison requiring students to evaluate a claim about loudness based on wave properties. Students must connect amplitude to loudness and distinguish it from frequency and wavelength.
SEP Justification: Students evaluate a scientific claim using evidence from wave diagrams. Engages Engaging in Argument from Evidence by assessing whether the claim is supported by the wave property data (amplitude determines loudness).
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that loudness is determined by amplitude (not frequency or wavelength). Students must apply wave property knowledge to evaluate a claim. Goes beyond recall to distinguishing related but different wave properties.
CCC Justification: Engages Patterns — students must recognize that amplitude (not frequency or wavelength) correlates with loudness. Also engages Cause and Effect — greater amplitude causes louder sound.
Key Recommendation: Good claim-evaluation question about wave properties. Strengthen by providing numerical amplitude and frequency data for each monkey's sound and asking students to rank loudness AND pitch separately with explanations.

Stem: Alex built a model solar-powered boat and wants to add more solar panels. Which question does NOT need to be tested through experimentation?
Choices: A) How many panels can the boat hold without sinking? B) Will solar panels float in water? C) Does adding more panels make the boat faster? D) How does panel angle affect energy collection?
Scenario Justification: Engineering design context where students must distinguish testable experimental questions from questions answerable through prior knowledge or simple observation. Meta-cognitive engagement with the nature of investigation.
SEP Justification: Students evaluate which question does not require experimentation. Engages Planning and Carrying Out Investigations by reasoning about which questions require testing and which can be answered through existing knowledge (solar panels are not designed to float independently).
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of what constitutes a testable question in engineering design. The reasoning is somewhat straightforward — whether solar panels float is a known property not requiring experimentation in this context.
CCC Justification: Implicitly engages Cause and Effect (experimentation tests causal relationships) but at a meta-cognitive level rather than direct application.
Key Recommendation: Good meta-cognitive question about experimental design. Strengthen by presenting all four questions and asking students to design a fair test for ONE of them, engaging Planning and Carrying Out Investigations more deeply.

Stem: A diagram shows how mountains form. Which statement BEST describes the process shown?
Image/Diagram Description: Diagram showing two tectonic plates pushing against each other with mountains forming at the boundary
Choices: A) Two plates pushed against each other causing the land to fold upward forming mountains, B) Wind erosion carved the mountains over time, C) Volcanoes erupted and created the mountain range, D) Water deposited sediment that hardened into mountains
Scenario Justification: Diagram-based question about mountain formation through plate tectonics. Students must interpret a visual model of convergent plate boundaries and connect it to the correct geological process.
SEP Justification: Students analyze and interpret a diagram/model of mountain formation. Engages Developing and Using Models by reading and explaining what a scientific model represents.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that mountains can form when tectonic plates converge and the land folds upward. Applied understanding of plate tectonics and landform formation beyond simple recall.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect — plates pushing together (cause) creates mountains through folding (effect). Also engages Stability and Change — the slow process of mountain building represents major change over geological time.
Key Recommendation: Good diagram interpretation question about plate tectonics. Elevate by asking a Part B: What evidence might scientists find in the mountain rocks that supports this explanation of how they formed?

Stem: A map shows earthquake patterns around the world. Identify TWO locations where major earthquakes are most likely to occur.
Image/Diagram Description: Map showing global earthquake patterns along tectonic plate boundaries with labeled locations
Choices: A) Location on a plate boundary, B) Location in the middle of a plate, C) Location far from plate boundaries, D) Location on another plate boundary
Scenario Justification: Map-based analysis of earthquake distribution patterns. Students must interpret a map showing earthquake patterns and identify locations at plate boundaries. Visual data analysis with real-world application.
SEP Justification: Students analyze and interpret spatial data from a map showing earthquake patterns. Engages Analyzing and Interpreting Data by identifying the pattern of earthquake concentration along plate boundaries.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that earthquakes concentrate along tectonic plate boundaries. Students must apply this understanding to a map to predict likely earthquake locations.
CCC Justification: Engages Patterns — students must recognize the spatial pattern of earthquakes along plate boundaries and use it to predict future locations. Core CCC application.
Key Recommendation: Good pattern recognition question using earthquake data. Elevate by asking students to explain WHY earthquakes cluster along plate boundaries rather than just identifying where they occur.

Stem: Which of the following is NOT an example of a renewable resource?
Choices: A) Solar energy, B) Wind energy, C) Coal, D) Water power
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Pure classification/recall question identifying the non-renewable resource from a list. No reasoning required beyond knowing definitions.
SEP Justification: No science practice engaged. Pure vocabulary recall — classifying resources as renewable or non-renewable.
DCI Justification: Tests knowledge of the definition of renewable vs. non-renewable resources. Coal is non-renewable because it cannot be replenished in a human timescale. Recall-level.
CCC Justification: No CCC engaged. No reasoning about patterns, systems, or causation.
Key Recommendation: Pure recall classification. Redesign to present data about resource consumption rates and replenishment rates and ask students to determine which resources are sustainable and explain why using Stability and Change reasoning.

Stem: Which TWO statements describe benefits of using renewable resources?
Choices: A) They are less expensive to maintain over time, B) They always produce the same amount of energy, C) They require no technology to use, D) They are safer for the environment
Scenario Justification: Students must identify benefits of renewable resources from a list. Some reasoning required to evaluate each claim but the question is essentially classification of true vs. false statements about renewables.
SEP Justification: Students evaluate claims about renewable resources. Engages Engaging in Argument from Evidence at a basic level — selecting accurate claims from options. Limited analytical depth.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of the advantages of renewable resources (cost efficiency and environmental safety). Recall-level with some applied reasoning to evaluate each statement.
CCC Justification: Implicitly engages Cause and Effect (renewable resources cause less environmental harm) but at a surface level.
Key Recommendation: Classification of true/false statements about renewables. Redesign to present cost and environmental data comparing renewable and non-renewable energy sources and ask students to analyze the data and make an evidence-based recommendation.

Stem: A city uses salt on roads in winter to prevent ice. A researcher suggests sand might be better. Which evidence supports the claim that sand is a better choice?
Choices: A) Sand is available in more colors, B) Salt has been used for decades, C) Sand dissolves faster than salt, D) Sand provides grip for tires and is less expensive
Scenario Justification: Engineering solution comparison scenario. Students must evaluate evidence that supports one solution over another. Requires reasoning about what constitutes relevant supporting evidence for a design claim.
SEP Justification: Students evaluate evidence to support an engineering design claim. Engages Engaging in Argument from Evidence by identifying which evidence supports the claim that sand is better than salt.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding engineering trade-offs (function and cost) and identifying relevant evidence. Applied understanding of solution evaluation in an engineering context.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect — sand provides grip (functional cause-effect) and costs less (economic criterion). Students must evaluate multiple criteria simultaneously.
Key Recommendation: Good evidence evaluation question. Strengthen by providing data about both salt and sand (cost per mile, accident rates, environmental impact) and asking students to make an evidence-based recommendation weighing multiple criteria.

Stem: Engineers are designing a sea wall to protect a coastal town from storm waves. What is the best way to test their model before building the real thing?
Choices: A) Ask residents if they think it will work, B) Look at pictures of other sea walls, C) Build the full-size wall and see what happens, D) Build a small model in a pool and create waves to test it
Scenario Justification: Engineering design scenario about testing a model before full-scale construction. Students must reason about the best approach to testing a design solution. Real-world engineering context.
SEP Justification: Students evaluate testing approaches for an engineering design. Engages Planning and Carrying Out Investigations and Developing and Using Models by identifying that building and testing a scale model is the appropriate approach.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that engineers use scale models to test designs before building full-size structures. Applied understanding of the engineering design process and the role of models in testing.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect — testing the model with waves (cause) reveals how well the design performs (effect). Basic causal reasoning about the purpose of testing.
Key Recommendation: Good question about the engineering design process. Elevate by asking a follow-up: What specific measurements should the engineers collect during their model test to determine if the design is effective?

Stem: After the 2017 Mexico earthquake caused severe building damage, engineers were asked to design new buildings. Which statement describes the BEST design criteria for the new buildings?
Choices: A) Design buildings that are the tallest possible, B) Design buildings that can absorb the force of an earthquake to reduce damage, C) Design buildings that are the cheapest to construct, D) Design buildings that look the most modern
Scenario Justification: Real-world engineering design scenario connected to an actual earthquake event. Students must identify appropriate design criteria for earthquake-resistant buildings from options that include irrelevant criteria.
SEP Justification: Students define design criteria based on a real problem. Engages Defining Problems by identifying that the core criterion should address the earthquake hazard (absorbing force to reduce damage). Connects to the engineering design process.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that engineering design criteria should directly address the identified problem (earthquake damage). Applied understanding of how to define appropriate engineering design criteria.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect — earthquake forces cause damage so buildings should absorb force (cause-effect reasoning about the solution). Basic CCC application.
Key Recommendation: Good real-world engineering context. Strengthen by providing data on building damage patterns from the earthquake and asking students to identify which structural features failed and propose specific design improvements based on the evidence.
